      Constructs a Decimal given a java.lang.Bignum Unfortunately, Bignum does NOT provide access to its data members so we have to take the roundabout way of converting to string.

      void unpackPrecision(short prec)
      Interprets prec to extract: pdigs - precision, i.e., total digits pscale - scale, i.e., digits after decimal pt to retain Note: Interprets low byte depending on whether timestamp flg is set If timestamp, then uses low 4 bits of low byte as end time indicator (@see #TU_YEAR etc) and computes scale from that.

        public Decimal(short exp,
       short pos,
       short ndgts,
       byte[] d)
        Constructor given basic fields as separate arg
        Parameters:
        exp - base 100 exponent
        pos - sign (1 pos, 0, neg, -1 null)
        ndgts - base 100 digits
        d - array of digits packed 2 per byte

      • Decimal

        public Decimal(byte[] cp)
        For debugging only Unlike the other constructors, this one expects bytes[0,1] to contain the length of the remaining bytes. Use this for debugging only to feed back the byte array produced by javaToIfx(). Note: As of 5/10/96, precision is returned via a separate method But since it is not available pass a 0 by default

      • Decimal

        public Decimal(byte[] cp,
       short prec)
        Converts bytes as received from IFX server into a Decimal obj
        Parameters:
        cp - should contain only the data bytes
        prec - precision

      • Decimal

        public Decimal(byte[] cp,
       int offset,
       int length,
       short prec)
        Converts bytes as received from IFX server into a Decimal obj
        Parameters:
        cp - byte array containing a decimal in network format
        offset - offset into array where decimal data begins
        length - length of decimal data in byte array
        prec - precision

      • Decimal

        public Decimal(byte[] cp,
       short prec,
       boolean ts)
        Converts bytes as received from IFX server into a Decimal obj but interpreted as a timestamp data
        Parameters:
        cp - should contain only the data bytes
        prec - precision
        ts - if true then interped as timestamp. default is false

      • Decimal

        public Decimal(byte[] cp,
       int offset,
       int length,
       short prec,
       boolean ts)
        Converts bytes as received from IFX server into a Decimal obj but interpreted as a timestamp data
        Parameters:
        cp - should contain only the data bytes
        offset - offset into cp byte array
        length - length of data
        prec - precision
        ts - if true then interped as timestamp. default is false

      • Decimal

        public Decimal(java.lang.String num)
        Creates Decimal from a string form of a decimal number of the form created by Bignum or by hand.
        Parameters:
        string - the string from which Decimal is created Format of input string: Optional sign in first place. Optional decimal pt anywhere Optional exponent of the form "e+-nnn" at end. However, if exponent is given then a decimal pt must precede it somewhere in the number. Thus, "123e-034" is invalid. This format is based on the one apparently used by java floats. No other chars allowed. Dont add spaces either!!

      • Decimal

        public Decimal(java.lang.String num,
       short inPrec)

      • Decimal

        public Decimal(java.math.BigDecimal n)
        Constructs a Decimal given a java.lang.Bignum Unfortunately, Bignum does NOT provide access to its data members so we have to take the roundabout way of converting to string. Sigh!!
        Parameters:
        n - Bignum from which equivalent Decimal is created

    • Method Detail

      • setTimestampQualifier

        public final void setTimestampQualifier(short qualifier)

      • setT

        public final void setT()

      • unpackPrecision

        public final void unpackPrecision(short prec)
        Interprets prec to extract: pdigs - precision, i.e., total digits pscale - scale, i.e., digits after decimal pt to retain Note: Interprets low byte depending on whether timestamp flg is set If timestamp, then uses low 4 bits of low byte as end time indicator (@see #TU_YEAR etc) and computes scale from that. Else treats low byte as number of digits after dec pt

      • computePrecision

        protected void computePrecision()

      • computeScale

        protected void computeScale()

      • getPrecision

        public byte[] getPrecision()
        Returns the precision as a 2-byte array

      • init

        protected void init(byte[] cp,
        int offset,
        int length,
        short prec)
        Given a packed byte array of the form received from IFX servers creates Decimal. The precision and length bytes should be stripped out before this is called. Note: Interprets the byte array in a very special form so dont use this unless the byte array is really coming from IFX servers or strictly equivalent code.
        Parameters:
        cp - byte[0] - contains the exponent in an encoded form rest of the bytes - packed digits in the number (base 100)
        prec - encoded information about the precision of the decimal with b[0] - precision and b[1] - scale if prec =0 then uses the precision inherent in the number

      • extractExponent

        protected int extractExponent(java.lang.String num,
                  int start)
        Given number string checks if it contains an exponent checking from start char. Exponent if given must be of the form: e+-nnn. Returns a number equal to the exponent Returns 0 if no exponent found.
        Parameters:
        num - number as a string which may have an exponent
        start - position where to start looking in string

        fromStart - index of first char copied
        fromEnd - index of last char copied

      • decComplement

        public static byte[] decComplement(byte[] b,
                   int start)
        Takes 100s complement of the given byte array starting from the end, backwards upto the "start" byte Process: byte[n] = 100- byte[n] byte[0] .. byte[n-1] = 99 - byte[i]
        Parameters:
        b - array of bytes packed with base 100 digits
        start - index of first byte to complement

      • javaToIfx

        public byte[] javaToIfx()
        Converts Decimal to byte array for sending out to IFX servers The format of the bytes is as follows: b[0], b[1] - length of bytes from b[2] on b[2] .. packed format as defined in decimal.h Note: While the precision is also transmitted to IFX, it is computed separately and written to the "output" before these bytes.

      • javaToDec_t

        public byte[] javaToDec_t()
        Convert Decimal to byte array that's in Informix dec_t format as defined in decimal.h.

        to - last base 100 digit

        public static byte[] encodeDateTimePrecision(byte[] b,
                             byte s,
                             byte e)
        Encodes precision for Datetime for transmission to IFX See the macro TU_DTENCODE in the IFX file datetime.h
        Parameters:
        b - 2 byte array where precision is created
        s - byte containing code for start time unit
        e - byte containing code for end time unit
        See Also:
        TU_YEAR, TU_MONTH, TU_F5

      • encodeIntervalPrecision

                             byte len,
                             byte s,
                             byte e)
        Encodes precision for interval for transmission to IFX See the macro TU_IENCODE in the IFX file datetime.h
        Parameters:

        e - byte containing code for end time unit
        See Also:
        TU_YEAR, TU_MONTH, TU_F5

      • tuFLen

        public static int tuFLen(short len)

      • timestampValue

        public java.sql.Timestamp timestampValue()
        Interprets this as a DateTime that was encoded as a decimal by IFX and returns a java.sql.Timestamp. Interprets the pscale as follows: high 4 bits: Start Time unit (0-15) low 4 bits: End Time Unit (0-15) These time units are strictly as defined in IFX datetime.h They are also defined in this file as TU_xxx Note: IFX DateTime can specify a date in a subset of the full range [YR .. NANOSEC] allowed by Java Timestamp. This creates two problems a. What to do with partial IFX DateTimes when converting to Java Timestamp? Backfill current date? Set unspecified fields to 0? Solution: Unspecified higher precision fields are backfilled from current time. Lower precision ones are set to 0. Thus if precision in IFX was MONTH .. MIN, then year is taken from current but SEC and NANO set to 0 b. How to send Java Timestamp back to IFX when the IFX is only expecting a partial DateTime (based on the precision there). The problem here is how best to preserve the precision info that came from IFX and use it on the way back. Solution: Send as in the java.Timestamp with fractional part truncated to 5 digits

      • timestampValue

        public java.sql.Timestamp timestampValue(java.util.Calendar cal)

      • intervalValue

        public Interval intervalValue()
